On Spheres, Shadows, and Certainty

July 6, 2025
math essay

A good mathematical puzzle often begins not with a question, but with a statement—one so elegant it feels both obvious and impossible. For me, this moment arrived during a commute, watching a 3Blue1Brown video featuring Terence Tao1. At one point, a theorem was presented (somewhat casually): if every possible 2D projection of a convex 3D body is a perfect disk, that body must be a sphere.

We see it with balls and flashlights, but how can we be certain that the shadow of a sphere is always a perfect disk? Not just for a sphere at the origin, or a shadow on a horizontal plane, but for any sphere and any plane?

Can we prove, with rigorous certainty, that the orthogonal projection of a sphere onto a plane is always a disk? I set out to answer it for myself, in hot pursuit of two distinct mathematical paths.

A Crucial Distinction: Intersection vs. Projection

Before diving into a proof, it’s essential to distinguish between two related concepts:

  • Intersection: This is the one-dimensional slice created when a plane cuts through a sphere. It is the curve where the two surfaces meet.

  • Projection: This is the two-dimensional shadow the sphere casts on a plane from a light source at an infinite distance, where all the incident light rays are parallel and perpendicular to the plane2.

Understanding the shape of the slice is the logical first step. If we can define the intersection, we can understand the projection.

The Vector Algebra Approach

I wanted to sidestep purely intuitive “it’s symmetric” arguments and construct a proof that holds for a plane of any orientation. The language of vector algebra is perfectly suited for this task.

The Setup

We can define our objects with two simple conditions:

  1. The Sphere: A sphere centered at the origin is the set of all points PPP in 3D space whose distance from the origin is a constant radius rrr. In vector terms: ∣P∣2=P⋅P=r2|P|^2 = P \cdot P = r^2∣P∣2=P⋅P=r2
  2. The Plane: An arbitrary plane3 passing through the origin is the set of all points PPP whose position vectors are orthogonal to a fixed unit normal vector nnn. The condition is: P⋅n=0P \cdot n = 0P⋅n=0

The intersection is simply the set of all points PPP that satisfy both conditions simultaneously.

Building a Coordinate System in the Plane

To analyze the shape of the intersection, we need a coordinate system that lies within the arbitrary plane. We can construct one using two perpendicular unit vectors, uuu and vvv, that span the plane.

  • Let uuu be any unit vector orthogonal to nnn.

  • Let vvv be the cross product v=n×uv = n \times uv=n×u.

This guarantees vvv is a unit vector orthogonal to both nnn and uuu. Since both uuu and vvv are orthogonal to the plane’s normal nnn, they form a basis for the plane. Any point PPP in the plane can be written as a combination of these vectors:

P=au+bvP = au + bvP=au+bv

where (a,b)(a, b)(a,b) are the 2D coordinates of the point within the plane’s own coordinate system.

The Final Step

Now, we enforce the sphere condition, ∣P∣2=r2|P|^2 = r^2∣P∣2=r2, on our point in the plane:

∣au+bv∣2=r2|au+bv|^2 = r^2∣au+bv∣2=r2 (au+bv)⋅(au+bv)=r2(au+bv) \cdot (au+bv) = r^2(au+bv)⋅(au+bv)=r2

Expanding the dot product yields:

a2(u⋅u)+2ab(u⋅v)+b2(v⋅v)=r2a^2(u \cdot u) + 2ab(u \cdot v) + b^2(v \cdot v) = r^2a2(u⋅u)+2ab(u⋅v)+b2(v⋅v)=r2

By our construction, uuu and vvv are orthonormal, meaning:

u⋅u=∣u∣2=1u \cdot u = |u|^2 = 1u⋅u=∣u∣2=1 v⋅v=∣v∣2=1v \cdot v = |v|^2 = 1v⋅v=∣v∣2=1 u⋅v=0u \cdot v = 0u⋅v=0

Substituting these values gives us the simple result:

a2(1)+2ab(0)+b2(1)=r2a^2(1) + 2ab(0) + b^2(1) = r^2a2(1)+2ab(0)+b2(1)=r2 a2+b2=r2a^2 + b^2 = r^2a2+b2=r2

This is the unmistakable equation of a circle of radius rrr. We have proven that the intersection of a sphere with any central plane is a perfect circle.

From Slice to Shadow: Proving the Projection

With the geometry of the slice confirmed, we can now tackle the shadow itself.

The Projection Formula

The orthogonal projection of any vector PPP from the sphere’s surface onto the plane is found by subtracting the component of PPP that is parallel to the normal vector nnn:

Pproj=P−(P⋅n)nP_{\text{proj}} = P - (P \cdot n)nPproj​=P−(P⋅n)n

We want to find the shape traced by PprojP_{\text{proj}}Pproj​ as PPP moves over the entire sphere. We can do this by calculating the squared distance of any projected point from the origin:

∣Pproj∣2=(P−(P⋅n)n)⋅(P−(P⋅n)n)|P_{\text{proj}}|^2 = (P - (P \cdot n)n) \cdot (P - (P \cdot n)n)∣Pproj​∣2=(P−(P⋅n)n)⋅(P−(P⋅n)n)

Using the distributive property of the dot product and the facts that P⋅P=r2P \cdot P = r^2P⋅P=r2 and n⋅n=1n \cdot n = 1n⋅n=1, the expression simplifies wonderfully:

∣Pproj∣2=r2−(P⋅n)2|P_{\text{proj}}|^2 = r^2 - (P \cdot n)^2∣Pproj​∣2=r2−(P⋅n)2

In simple terms, this equation says that the squared distance of the shadow from the center is the sphere’s squared radius minus the point’s squared height above the plane. This is the Pythagorean theorem in disguise.

The Conclusion

This final equation is powerfully conclusive. The term (P⋅n)2(P \cdot n)^2(P⋅n)2 is a squared value, so it must be positive or zero. This implies a critical inequality:

∣Pproj∣2≤r2|P_{\text{proj}}|^2 \le r^2∣Pproj​∣2≤r2

This states that the squared distance of any point in the shadow is less than or equal to the squared radius of the sphere. The set of all points on a plane satisfying this condition is, by definition, a disk—a filled circle. The boundary of this disk, a circle of radius rrr, is formed by points on the sphere’s “equator” relative to the plane, where P⋅n=0P \cdot n = 0P⋅n=0.

An Alternate Path: The View from Spherical Coordinates

Despite the ordering of this article, my first instinct was not vector algebra, but to describe the geometry using angles. This approach, using spherical coordinates, offers a different but equally compelling perspective.

The Setup

We define our point and plane using angles. The intuition is that since a plane is given by its normal vector, we can parametrize its “tilt” using spherical coordinates.

  1. A point on a sphere PPP: Its location is given by spherical coordinates (r,θ,ϕ)(r, \theta, \phi)(r,θ,ϕ). P=⟨rsin⁡ϕcos⁡θ,rsin⁡ϕsin⁡θ,rcos⁡ϕ⟩P = \langle r\sin\phi\cos\theta, r\sin\phi\sin\theta, r\cos\phi \rangleP=⟨rsinϕcosθ,rsinϕsinθ,rcosϕ⟩
  2. A plane through the origin: Its orientation is defined by the fixed angles (θ0,ϕ0)(\theta_0, \phi_0)(θ0​,ϕ0​) of its unit normal vector nnn. n=⟨sin⁡ϕ0cos⁡θ0,sin⁡ϕ0sin⁡θ0,cos⁡ϕ0⟩n = \langle \sin\phi_0\cos\theta_0, \sin\phi_0\sin\theta_0, \cos\phi_0 \ranglen=⟨sinϕ0​cosθ0​,sinϕ0​sinθ0​,cosϕ0​⟩

Again, the condition for a point to lie on the intersection is that its position vector is orthogonal to the normal vector:

P⋅n=0P \cdot n = 0P⋅n=0

The Calculation and Conclusion

Computing the dot product with coordinates yields a complicated expression. After factoring and applying the cosine angle-subtraction identity, we arrive at:

sin⁡ϕsin⁡ϕ0cos⁡(θ−θ0)+cos⁡ϕcos⁡ϕ0=0\sin\phi\sin\phi_0\cos(\theta - \theta_0) + \cos\phi\cos\phi_0 = 0sinϕsinϕ0​cos(θ−θ0​)+cosϕcosϕ0​=0

This equation is a special case of the Spherical Law of Cosines4. It is a more complex way of stating that cos⁡(γ)=0\cos(\gamma) = 0cos(γ)=0, where γ\gammaγ is the angle between the vector PPP and the normal vector nnn.

We could also recall a geometric definition of the dot product:

P⋅n=∣P∣∣n∣cos⁡γP \cdot n = |P| |n| \cos\gammaP⋅n=∣P∣∣n∣cosγ

Since ∣P∣∣n∣=r>0|P||n| = r > 0∣P∣∣n∣=r>0, the only way for the above expression to be zero is for cos⁡(γ)\cos(\gamma)cos(γ) to be zero; that is, the angle γ\gammaγ must be a constant 90 degrees.

This forces every point PPP on the intersection to lie at a fixed 90° angle from the axis defined by nnn. On the surface of a sphere, the set of all points at a constant 90° angle from a central axis is, by definition, a great circle5.

Certainty in a Shadow

My curiosity has now been put to rest.

Footnotes

  1. I highly encourage you to watch the video that sparked this inquiry: Terence Tao on measuring the cosmos | The Distance Ladder Part 1. ↩

  2. This “infinitely far” condition is crucial. A nearby light source would cast a shadow that is a different conic section—typically an ellipse. The assumption of parallel rays is the basis for an orthographic projection. ↩

  3. This proof assumes the plane passes through the sphere’s center. For a non-central plane at a distance ddd from the origin, the intersection is still a circle, but with a smaller radius of r2−d2\sqrt{r^2 - d^2}r2−d2​. Remarkably, the projection’s shadow remains a disk of radius rrr. ↩

  4. The realization that this formula was a known identity came during my exploration of the problem. ↩

  5. A great circle is a circle on a sphere’s surface whose center coincides with the sphere’s center. If the plane does not pass through the center, the intersection is a small circle, like the Earth’s lines of latitude. ↩
